importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the latest update to the story, indicating the most current information on the stalled Trump-Putin summit plans.
The date of the latest development in diplomatic talks between Rubio and Lavrov, signaling the current state of U.S.-Russia engagement.

importantTimeframes.approximateTimeFrameStart: immediately following a Thursday phone call
importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Initial Trump-Putin summit timeline that has now been abandoned, reflecting a shift in diplomatic expectations.

importantTimeframes.approximateTimeFrameStart: immediately following a Monday phone call
importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Planned meeting between U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov, now deemed unnecessary.

keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump's hopes for a quick summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin have been abandoned, with no immediate plans for a meeting.
A previous timeline of a Trump-Putin summit within two weeks has stalled due to lack of progress from the Russian side and divergent views on ending the war in Ukraine.
Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov held a productive phone call, but no further in-person meeting is currently planned.
The Kremlin has stated that no summit date was ever set, so it cannot be postponed, emphasizing that the meeting remains uncommitted.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky suggests that Russia’s reduced interest in diplomacy may stem from the U.S. withholding long-range missile support for Ukraine.
Zelensky argues that greater Ukrainian long-range capabilities would increase Russia’s willingness to end the war.
Senior administration officials believe that Russian Foreign Minister Lavrov is not a key decision-maker and that talks with him are largely symbolic.
There remains a possibility of future diplomatic coordination between Rubio and Lavrov at an ASEAN-led multilateral summit.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former President of the United States (current president in this article)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump is central to the article as the driving force behind the proposal for a rapid summit with Putin, which has now been abandoned, highlighting shifts in U.S. foreign policy priorities.

namedEntities.name: Vladimir Putin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Putin is the key counterpart to Trump in the proposed summit; his position on the war in Ukraine and unwillingness to move from maximalist stances underlines the diplomatic impasse.

namedEntities.name: Marco Rubio
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rubio represents the U.S. diplomatic front in engaging with Russia, and his disagreements with Lavrov over the war's end signal a breakdown in bilateral coordination.

namedEntities.name: Sergey Lavrov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Lavrov is the primary Russian diplomatic representative in talks with Rubio, and his lack of influence and loyalty to Putin reflect the limited effectiveness of diplomatic engagement.

namedEntities.name: Volodymyr Zelensky
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Zelensky provides a critical perspective on the war's diplomatic trajectory, arguing that long-range missile support from the U.S. is a key factor in Russia’s willingness to negotiate.

namedEntities.name: Dmitry Peskov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Peskov represents the Russian government’s official stance, stating that no summit date was set and thus cannot be postponed.

namedEntities.name: ASEAN
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: ASEAN is proposed as a venue for potential future diplomatic talks between Rubio and Lavrov, signaling an alternative path for U.S.-Russia engagement.

summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump’s hopes for a quick summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin have stalled, with the U.S. administration now stating there are no immediate plans for a meeting. This comes after Trump initially suggested a summit within two weeks following a phone call, but subsequent diplomatic efforts — including a call between U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov — revealed divergent positions on ending the war in Ukraine. Officials say that Lavrov, while loyal to Putin, is not involved in major decisions and thus does not drive meaningful progress. The Kremlin maintains that no summit date was ever set, so postponement is not possible. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky asserts that Russia’s reduced interest in diplomacy stems from the U.S. withholding long-range missile support for Ukraine, suggesting that such capabilities are essential to achieving peace. While no immediate summit is expected, future discussions between Rubio and Lavrov may take place at an ASEAN-led multilateral meeting.
title: Trump’s hopes for quick second summit with Putin have stalled out
